text: This presentation covers the earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year of 2023.
Our Vision is to be the preeminent banking partner for institutions with cross-border needs, a global leader in wealth management, and a valued personal bank in our home market.
The company is focused on delivering on its Investor Day priorities through four key elements: Transformation, Investment for Growth, Simplification, and Culture & Talent.
Transformation efforts include relentless execution, regulatory remediation, modernizing infrastructure, and data enhancements.
Growth investments are aimed at maximizing the global network, growing the Commercial Banking sector, scaling Wealth, and gaining share in Banking, Markets, and U.S. Personal Banking.
Simplification strategy involves focusing on five core interconnected businesses, exiting 14 international consumer markets, and simplifying the organizational structure.
The company aims to build a winning culture, invest in talent, and deliver 'One Citi'.
The company is being run differently by aligning its organizational structure to its business strategy, eliminating multiple management layers, and bringing clients closer to the center.
A new client organization focused on 5 core businesses aims to drive top-line revenue growth and synergies.
The new structure is designed to reduce duplicative governance, enable more efficient business operations by right-sizing the expense base, and increase accountability and transparency.
The five core businesses are Services, Markets, Banking, Wealth, and U.S. Personal Banking (USPB).
Services holds top rankings, including #1 in TTS and #1 in Direct Custody.
Markets is ranked #3 overall, with Fixed Income at #2 and Equities at #6.
Banking is ranked #5 in Investment Banking.
Wealth's Private Bank is tied for the #5 rank.
USPB is ranked #2 in U.S. Cards and #1 in deposits per branch.
Returned approximately $6 billion in capital to common shareholders through dividends and share buybacks.
Services had a record year for TTS revenues and gained ~70bps of market share YoY in 3Q YTD.
Markets saw progress in Equities with prime balances up YoY.
Banking grew its share in Investment Banking, with DCM wallet share up ~30bps.
Wealth's Client Investment Assets were up $55B YoY.
USPB showed continued momentum in cards, with average loans up 13% YoY.
In 'All Other', the company closed 4 remaining sales and made strong progress on wind-downs.
Transformation progress in 2023 includes closing the FX Consent Order, retiring ~390 legacy applications, and automating processes for price verification and transaction controls.
Strategic execution highlights include continued strength in Services (TTS #1), Markets remaining #2 in FICC, a 6th straight quarter of revenue growth in Cards, and stronger growth in Wealth in 4Q.
Progress on divestitures included closing all nine signed Asia divestitures with a ~$6B capital benefit and being on track to complete the Mexico separation in 2H 2024.
Key organizational changes were announced to align structure with strategy and simplify decision making, with the program set to conclude in 1Q24.

The company is executing with excellence across all priorities to unlock value through driving revenue growth, disciplined expense management, maintaining robust capital and liquidity, and improving returns over the medium-term.
Revenues decreased (3)% YoY, driven by the Argentina devaluation impact, lower volatility in Markets, and a slow recovery in IB and Wealth.
Expenses were up 23% YoY, primarily due to the FDIC special assessment and restructuring charges.
Credit Costs were $3.5B, including a $1.3B ACL build associated with transfer risk in Russia and Argentina, and higher Card NCLs returning to pre-Covid levels.
Net Income was a loss of $(1.8)B, as higher expenses and credit costs more than offset the lower revenues.
FY Revenues were $77.1B ex-divestitures and $47.6B NII ex-Markets.
Services revenue was up 16% YoY, driven by higher interest rates, new client wins, and market appreciation.
Markets revenue was down (6)% YoY, largely due to rates, currencies, equity derivatives, and the Argentina devaluation.
Banking revenue was down (15)% YoY, in line with the market wallet, but was partially offset by progress in areas like Healthcare.
Wealth revenue was down (5)% YoY, driven by a deposit product mix shift and lower investment fees.
U.S. Personal Banking revenue was up 14% YoY, driven by a rebound in borrowing on cards and innovation in digital acquisitions.
Full year 2023 expenses of $54.3B ex-divestitures and FDIC Special Assessment were in line with the guidance of ~$54B.
Transformation investments were driven by efforts to modernize infrastructure, automate processes, and enhance data analytics.
Business-led investments focused on product innovations, front office talent, and technology platforms to drive revenue.
Volume-related expenses grew due to marketing, transaction-related costs, and incentive compensation.
Structural and other expenses were driven by risk and control enhancements, technology investments, and macro factors like inflation.

Transformation expense on Technology includes automating price verification for over 90% of Fixed Income and Equity securities and launching new capabilities for Strategic Wholesale Credit Production.
Transformation spending on Consultants was reduced by replacing them with internal hires.
Growth in transformation-related Compensation was largely driven by additional headcount in Data and Risk & Control.

Change-the-Bank technology spending reduced account opening cycle time by 40% for Private Bank and delivered a new cloud-based CitiDirect platform now used by over 70% of digital Corporate and Commercial users.
Run-the-Bank technology spending included deploying automation tools and a centralized security platform, which helped reduce Fraud Loss/Expense.
Total End of Period (EOP) consumer loans stood at $389 billion.
Total corporate lending exposure was $712 billion.
Revenues up 6% YoY for the quarter, driven by NII growth in TTS and Securities Services, but partially offset by lower NIR due to the Argentina currency devaluation.
Expenses increased 9% YoY, driven by investments in technology, product innovation, and client experience.
Credit costs of $646 million included a $652 million ACL build, primarily due to transfer risk in Russia and Argentina.
Net income was down (43)% YoY, as higher revenues were more than offset by increased credit costs and expenses.
RoTCE was 13.4% for 4Q23 and 20.0% for the full year.
Revenues were down (19)% YoY, driven by a (25)% decline in Fixed Income, which was partially offset by a 9% increase in Equities. Results were also impacted by the Argentina currency devaluation.
Expenses increased 8% YoY due to investments in transformation, risk and control, and volume-related costs.
Credit Costs of $209 million included an ACL build of $179 million, primarily for transfer risk in Russia and Argentina.
A Net Loss of $(134) million was reported, as revenues were more than offset by higher expenses and credit costs.
RoTCE was (1.0)% for 4Q23, and FY RoTCE was 7.4%.

Revenues were up 22% YoY, driven by 27% growth in Investment Banking revenues and lower losses on loan hedges, partially offset by a (26)% decline in Corporate Lending and the impact of Argentina currency devaluation.
Expenses rose 37% YoY, primarily due to the absence of an operational loss reserve release in the prior year.
Credit Costs were $185 million, mainly from a net reserve build for transfer risk in Russia and Argentina.
A Net Loss of $(322) million was recorded, driven by higher expenses and credit costs that were partially offset by higher revenues.
RoTCE was (6.0)% for 4Q23, and FY RoTCE was (0.2)%.
Revenues were down (3)% YoY, driven by lower deposit spreads, but partially offset by lower mortgage funding costs and higher investment fee revenues.
Expenses were up 4% YoY, primarily due to investments in risk and controls and technology.
Credit costs were $4 million, driven by NCLs of $31 million, but partially offset by an ACL release of $(27) million.
Net income was $5 million, reflecting lower revenues and higher expenses.
RoTCE was 0.1% for the quarter, and FY RoTCE was 2.6%.
Revenues were up 12% YoY, driven by an increase in NII from loan growth in cards and higher deposit spreads.
Expenses were down (1)% YoY, primarily driven by risk and control and business-led investments, which were more than offset by lower non-volume related expenses.
Credit costs were $2.1 billion, with NCLs of $1.6 billion reflecting a return to pre-Covid loss rates and an ACL build of $0.5 billion.
Net income was $201 million, driven by higher revenues and lower expenses, partially offset by higher cost of credit.
RoTCE was 3.6% for the quarter, and FY RoTCE was 8.3%.
Revenues were down (17)% YoY, driven by a decrease in NII from higher funding costs and closed exits, though partially offset by higher NIR. Mexico revenues increased 20% YoY.
Expenses were up 92% YoY, driven by the FDIC special assessment and restructuring costs, partially offset by lower expenses in both wind-down and exit markets.
Credit Costs were $459 million.

Drivers for NIR ex-Markets ex-Divestitures include TTS client wins, continued onboarding in Securities Services, a rebound in Investment Banking and Wealth, and lower partner payments in Retail Services.

Drivers for NII ex-Markets include modestly down YoY performance, global interest rates expected to come down, mid-single digits loan growth driven by cards, modest operating deposit growth, and the impact of closed exit and wind-down markets.
In 3Q23 YTD, the company took ~$600mm of severance related to 6k headcount, offset by hiring in technology, operations, and control initiatives.
In 4Q23, the company took ~$800mm of restructuring and ~$100mm of severance related to ~7k headcount.
For FY24, the company expects to take ~$700mm to $1.0B in severance and costs related to organizational simplification to further reduce headcount over the medium-term.
Over the medium-term, the company expects a net reduction in reported headcount of 20k.
Expense saves from organizational simplification, which may be offset by expenses related to revenue growth, are projected to be between ($2.0-2.5) billion.
Efficiencies are to be realized from Transformation efforts.
A new management and organizational structure is expected to reduce headcount.
Exiting international consumer businesses will reduce direct expenses and eliminate stranded costs.
Expect Net Credit Loss (NCL) rates in both Branded Cards and Retail Services portfolios to rise above pre-COVID levels in 2024.
Reserves are based on a weighted 8-quarter average unemployment rate of ~5.0% with a downside assumption of 6.8%.
Expect mid-single digit loan growth in both card portfolios.
Full year 2024 guidance includes revenues of ~$80-81 billion and expenses of ~$53.5-53.8 billion.
NII ex-Markets is expected to be down modestly YoY for the full year 2024.
Cost of Credit guidance for 2024 includes a Branded Cards average NCL rate of 3.50-4.00% and a Retail Services average NCL rate of 5.75-6.25%.
The company will continue to evaluate buybacks on a quarter-by-quarter basis.
Medium-term targets include a 4-5% revenue CAGR, reduced expenses from simplification, and 6-7% loan growth.
The company is committed to a medium-term RoTCE target of 11-12%.
Statements in the presentation are forward-looking, based on current expectations, and subject to uncertainty; they are not guarantees of future results.
Actual results may differ materially due to various factors, including Citi's ability to achieve objectives like expense savings from transformation and strategic initiatives.
Key risk factors include the divestiture of Mexico operations, potential U.S. government shutdown, interest rate impacts, potential recessions, and changes to regulatory rules like Basel III Endgame.
Other risks include inflation, geopolitical conflicts such as the war in Ukraine and conflict in the Middle East, and potential currency devaluations in Argentina.
Forward-looking statements are only as of the date they are made, and Citi does not undertake to update them.

HQLA: High quality liquid assets
SS: Securities Services
CCB: Commercial Client Banking
HTM: Held to Maturity

IG: Investment Grade
